published_attributes.title: Course Overview
published_attributes.serialized_body:
In this presentation I would like to share with you some useful tips regarding using Django. They won't be very innovative and you may already know some of them, but when I started my first job as a Python Web Developer, I didn't know all these things, and I find them very useful.

In this course you will learn:

  • How does Middleware work in Django
  • What are Signals and how to use them
  • About some ORM and migrations functionalities
  • Useful tips

This presentation consists of 7 slides and 2 quiz questions.

I wish you effective learning and good luck! :)

published_attributes.title: Middleware
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Middleware is a piece of code that is executed every time any request/response is being handled by application. In case of requests, this code is executed even before request reaches view.  That means you can do many types of operations there, for example add some information to request or perform some kind of analytics. 

Example for logging every incoming request:

Remember to add your Middleware class to MIDDLEWARE in settings file!

More info: https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/3.1/topics/http/middleware/

published_attributes.title: Custom migrations
published_attributes.serialized_body:
There will be no explanation here of what migrations are, as this is basic knowledge in Django. However, not all of beginners know that Django allows writing custom migrations. To do so, you can:

python manage.py make migrations app_name --empty

As a result, you get following template:

Now, you can write desired function:

And change generated migration file so it executes code above during migration:

If it's possible, you should provide reverse function, so there is a possibility to do database downgrade when needed. 

What are these usable for? For example fixing some broken data that already exists in database, populate rows and basically everything that you probably would do using shell, but it's better to have it reproducible in other environments and have a trace of that operation.

published_attributes.title: Signals
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Signals allow you to execute code right before or right after some events take place in application.

Here you can find a list of available signals in Django. Let's take a post_save for example - that means you can connect your code to a signal that will execute your function right after models are saved. You can also specify which models you are interested in.

Create a signals.py file in your app:

But creating such file doesn't mean Django will use it. You need to import this file in another file that will be imported early when your application starts. Application's apps.py is usually a good file to place that import:

As always, don't forget to include YourApp in installed applications.

You can find more information here. :)

published_attributes.title: Select / prefetch related
published_attributes.serialized_body:
These two methods are highly useful when there are foreign keys in your database - which means almost always.

For example:

Let's say you want to fetch all cars and print some information about them, including an owner:

Assuming we've got many cars in database - it would execute one SQL query for all the cars + one query per each car to fetch owner information. For example, for 500 cars in database, it would be 501 requests!

It can be improved really easy:

It would execute... one SQL query. Makes a huge difference, right?

Basically select_related and prefetch_related are similar, but in short: select_related is used when the object that you're going to select is a single object and prefetch_related is used when we’re going to get a set of things.

I encourage you to try it yourself :)

published_attributes.title: Custom management commands
published_attributes.serialized_body:
I'm sure you know a few managements commands in Django. For example: shell, createsuperuser, makemigrations or migrate. But did you know you can write your own management commands?

In the app of your choice create following directory structure:

Please, remember to include app in installed apps in settings file.

File with custom command has one requirement - it must define a class Command that extends BaseCommand or one of its subclasses. For example:

And now can be executed:

python manage.py custom_command

There are more possibilities for custom commands, you can read more about them in the documentation.

published_attributes.title: Other tips
published_attributes.serialized_body:
1. one import per line - greatly improves code readability

alternatively

instead of

2. split requirements into development and production

It installs requirements from requirements.txt file and those which you find useful during development stage.

3. for time consuming operations (for example sending messages) use a task queue such as Celery or Huey

published_attributes.title: Other Tips #2
published_attributes.serialized_body:
4. consider typing your Python code - even though Python is weakly typed, for better code readability and debugging you can type your code

Thanks to that, if you were to call for example foo("cat", "dog") your IDE could warn you that types of the passed variables are incorrect. 

5. use code formatters to avoid wasting time on prettifying code manually, for example black or pre-commit hooks.

6. Use environment variables as settings - you don’t want to store credentials or access keys directly in code, you can provide such values as environment variables (for example in .env file used in docker-compose)

Instead of
